head.title: Film in Review; A Dios Momo

block.p: Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Leonardo Ricagni In Spanish, with English subtitles Not rated; 108 minutes

Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Leonardo Ricagni In Spanish, with English subtitles Not rated; 108 minutes
''A Dios Momo,'' directed by Leonardo Ricagni, is to melodrama as corn syrup is to sweeteners: efficient but crude.

The film follows the uplifting misadventures of Obdulio (Mathias Acuña), a sweet-tempered 11-year-old newspaper boy who lives with his grandmother (Carmen Abella), a saintly old woman who is mainly pictured praying, and saves his pennies to buy school uniforms for his sisters.

Obdulio is illiterate and refuses to go to school, but he's obsessed with the Murgas, a troupe of traveling singers. This fascination blossoms into a willingness to learn when his newspaper's watchman, Barrilete (Jorge Esmoris), teaches him to read by dispatching him to the singers' practice room to scrawl Barrilete's lyrics on a chalkboard.

This fairy-tale touch might work if the movie weren't so eager to imitate the stalest aspects of the director's chief inspiration, Federico Fellini. (The visions of Obdulio chasing a mimelike apparition through the streets play like an outtake from ''Juliet of the Spirits'' as staged by the ''Waiting for Guffman'' auteur Corky St. Clair.)
It sounds churlish to bash a film that's as bereft of bad thoughts as a tiny puppy. But when the puppy licks your face for 108 minutes, enough's enough.
